clusters.title: X plans a Handle Marketplace for Premium+ and Business subscribers to search for and request inactive usernames; rare handles can cost from $2,500 to $1M+ (Terrence O'Brien/The Verge)
clusters.neutral_headline: X Plans Handle Marketplace for Premium Users

items.title: X plans a Handle Marketplace for Premium+ and Business subscribers to search for and request inactive usernames; rare handles can cost from $2,500 to $1M+ (Terrence O'Brien/The Verge)
items.standfirst: Terrence O'Brien / The Verge: X plans a Handle Marketplace for Premium+ and Business subscribers to search for and request inactive usernames; rare handles can cost from $2,500 to $1M+ — Premium subscribers will be able to search and request usernames that have been unavailable. … Handles are going to be broken up into two broad categories.
items.content: Terrence O'Brien / The Verge: X plans a Handle Marketplace for Premium+ and Business subscribers to search for and request inactive usernames; rare handles can cost from $2,500 to $1M+ — Premium subscribers will be able to search and request usernames that have been unavailable. … Handles are going to be broken up into two broad categories.

items.title: X is launching a marketplace for inactive handles
items.standfirst: Premium Plus and Premium Business users will soon be able to browse and request inactive usernames on the X Handle Marketplace. Handles are going to be broken up into two broad categories. Priority handles will be free and “often include full names, multi-word phrases, or alphanumeric combinations.” Rare handles, on the other hand, will be […]
items.content: Premium Plus and Premium Business users will soon be able to browse and request inactive usernames on the X Handle Marketplace. Handles are going to be broken up into two broad categories. Priority handles will be free and “often include full names, multi-word phrases, or alphanumeric combinations.” Rare handles, on the other hand, will be a paid option, and “may be priced anywhere from $2,500 to over seven figures, depending on demand and uniqueness.” X is treating this not as a one-time perk, but as an ongoing service to lure in more paid subscribers. If you secure a new handle, your old one will be frozen. The company says it may eventually offer a redirect option as a paid add-on. But more importantly, if you ever downgrade your X subscription, your account will revert back to your original username, and you’ll lose access to the one you snagged through the marketplace. The X Handle Marketplace is our industry-first solution to redistribute handles that are no longer in use. Eligible Premium subscribers will be able to search and make requests, with both complimentary and paid options available.— Handle Marketplace (@XHandles) October 19, 2025

ai_summary: X plans a Handle Marketplace for Premium+ and Business subscribers.
Users can search for and request inactive usernames.
Rare handles may cost from $2,500 to over $1 million.
Premium subscribers will be able to search and request handles.
Handles will be categorized into priority and rare types.

clusters.title: Something from “space” may have just struck a United Airlines flight over Utah
clusters.neutral_headline: Something From Space May Have Struck United Flight

items.title: Something from “space” may have just struck a United Airlines flight over Utah
items.standfirst: "NTSB gathering radar, weather, flight recorder data."
items.content: The National Transportation Safety Board confirmed Sunday that it is investigating an airliner that was struck by an object in its windscreen, mid-flight, over Utah. “NTSB gathering radar, weather, flight recorder data,” the federal agency said on the social media site X. “Windscreen being sent to NTSB laboratories for examination.” The strike occurred Thursday, during a United Airlines flight from Denver to Los Angeles. Images shared on social media showed that one of the two large windows at the front of a 737 MAX aircraft was significantly cracked. Related images also reveal a pilot’s arm that has been cut multiple times by what appear to be small shards of glass.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: An object from space may have struck a United Airlines flight.
The incident occurred over Utah.
The NTSB is gathering data on the event.
Radar, weather, and flight recorder data are being collected.
The NTSB is investigating the incident.

clusters.title: Roberta Williams’ The Colonel’s Bequest was a different type of adventure game
clusters.neutral_headline: Roberta Williams' Adventure Game Focused on Narrative, Not Puzzles

items.title: Roberta Williams’ The Colonel’s Bequest was a different type of adventure game
items.standfirst: What if point-and-click games weren't about the puzzles?
items.content: Even in my youth, I always loved the idea of point-and-click adventure games more than I did the reality. I appreciated how they transported me to other worlds, each with its own rules, histories, and interesting characters. However, like many people, I often ran up against the harsh reality of solving bizarre and obtuse puzzles in a time before Internet walkthroughs. I almost never actually finished point-and-click adventure games for that reason—but there is one major exception: I completed Roberta Williams’ The Colonel’s Bequest several times. One of the last Sierra adventure games to still use a text parser, The Colonel’s Bequest follows a young woman named Laura Bow as she visits a mansion in the Southern US belonging to her college friend’s grandfather, Colonel Henri Dijon. While she’s there, a dispute breaks out over the colonel’s will, and it becomes clear a murderer is on the loose.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: The Colonel's Bequest prioritized storytelling and atmosphere over traditional puzzle solving.
Roberta Williams' game design shifted focus away from puzzle-centric gameplay.
The game offered a different approach to the adventure game genre.
It emphasized exploration and character interaction within the narrative.
This approach distinguished it from other point-and-click adventure games.
